Zinc and magnesium catalysts for the synthesis for PLA and its degradation: Clues for catalyst design Federica Santulli Data curation Giuseppe Gravina Data curation Marina Lamberti Formal analysis Consiglia Tedesco Data curation Mina Mazzeo Conceptualization Visualization Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing ⁎ Dipartimento di Chimica e Biologia "Adolfo Zambelli", Università di Salerno, via Giovanni Paolo II, 132, Fisciano, SA 84084, Italy Dipartimento di Chimica e Biologia "Adolfo Zambelli" Università di Salerno via Giovanni Paolo II, 132 Fisciano SA 84084 Italy Dipartimento di Chimica e Biologia "Adolfo Zambelli", Università di Salerno, via Giovanni Paolo II, 132, Fisciano, SA 84084, Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. Homoleptic and heteroleptic zinc and magnesium complexes bearing phenoxy-imine pyridine ligands were synthetized and characterized. Several structural parameters such as the structure of the ancillary ligand, the nature of the metal centre and the coordination geometry were investigated for identifying design elements purposeful to improve the catalytic activity in the ring opening polymerization (ROP) of lactide and in the reverse reaction of degradation of polylactide by alcoholysis. High efficiency and control degree were reached with zinc catalysts while magnesium ones showed lower activity and a weak control degree. NMR studies demonstrated that, for the homoleptic zinc complex, an activated-monomer mechanism was active. Differently, a coordination/insertion mechanism was observed for the related homoleptic zinc complex. Significantly, the complexes that showed the best activity in the ROP of lactide revealed to be the most efficient also in the degradation reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polylactide Ring Opening Polymerization Zinc catalysts Depolymerization Methyl lactate Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In the contemporary economy plastics fill a dominant position. Because of their excellent mechanical properties and their high strength and durability, they have found large application in almost all industrial sectors and households [1]. On the other hand, the longevity of synthetic plastics, in combination with the absence of a correct strategy for their end-of-life management, caused grave environmental pollution. It has been estimated that around 60% of all plastics ever produced is accumulated in waste deposits or dispersed in the environment [1,2]. Since the plastic demand is predicted to increase, new strategies must be implemented to contrast this emergency. In this context, coherently with new concept of circular economy, the development of both new environmentally friendly materials [3,4] and efficient technologies for plastic recycling are strategic actions [5–7]. Poly(lactic acid) or polylactide (PLA) is a biodegradable plastic derived for renewable resources. Thanks to its good mechanical and gas barrier properties, it may express its potentiality as alternative to the traditional oil derived plastics for short single use food packaging [8–10]. However, despite its potential sustainability, criticisms about its life cycle must be still addressed. Currently, PLA is industrially produced by ring opening polymerization of lactide promoted by the highly toxic tin catalysts. Moreover, although PLA is a biodegradable material, currently its waste management plan is not well planned. PLA is a compostable material but industrial conditions, such as high temperature and humidity, are required. At the same time, the mechanical recycling is not very efficient because residual contaminants cause a significant loss of the mechanical properties of the recycled material. Recently, chemical depolymerization is emerging as a powerful method for recycling of PLA [11]. The implementation of efficient plastic recycling processes, in which waste materials are reconverted into the starting monomers or small molecules of added values, may represent a fruitful approach [6,12]. Specifically, from chemical recycling of PLA, lactate esters and lactic acid can be obtained wherein lactic acid has been identified as a platform chemical [13], whilst lactate esters are used as green solvents [14]. Motivated by the interest to discover new low-toxicity catalytic systems that could compete with the industrially employed catalysts for the synthesis of PLA [15], numerous catalytic systems based on non-toxic metals such as zinc [16–18], magnesium [19–22] and aluminium [23–26] have been developed which revealed high efficiency or unexpected abilities in controlling the microstructure [27–33] of the polymer or high efficiency [34]. At the same time, suitable models to rationalize the stereoselective lactide polymerization have been developed [35–38]. Differently, the examples of catalysts for the depolymerization of PLA by alcoholysis are rare [39]. Commercially available metal salts [40–42] and simple metal precursors such as Zn(HMDS)2 [43] have been explored as catalysts for alcoholysis of PLA to produce methyl lactate (Me-LA). Regarding metal complexes with well-defined structure, the first remarkable examples are the dinuclear alkoxide Zn–N-heterocyclic carbene complexes described by Dagorne that revealed to be efficient initiators for the ring-opening polymerization of lactide and for the controlled depolymerization of PLA by alcoholysis [44] and the salalen-based hafnium complexes reported by Whitelaw et al. [45]. More recently, several families of homoleptic Zn (II) and Mg(II) complexes bearing tridentate NNO [46,47] and ONS [48] ligands have been described for the transesterification of PLA. In these studies, the authors highlighted the importance of the structure of the ancillary ligand and the role of the additional amine donor [49,50]. Inspired by these studies, we recently introduced a new catalyst, a phenoxy-imine pyridine zinc amide complex that revealed to be a highly efficient catalyst in the ROP of LA and in the depolymerization of PLA under very mild reaction conditions [51]. Herein we extended these studies to homoleptic and heteroleptic magnesium and zinc complexes stabilized by phenoxy-imine ligands bearing an additional pyridine moiety that is a weaker base than amine and moreover it may behave as a hemilabile donor, offering the chance of a flexible coordination geometry, with the aim to elucidate the role of structural parameters advantageous for the catalytic activity. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis of complexes The proligand LH (Scheme 1 ) was obtained in high yield via a simple condensation reaction and characterized by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy. In the 1H NMR spectrum, a singlet at ca. δ = 7.75 ppm revealed the formation of the imine functionality. Two distinct triplets were observed at δ = 3.75 and 2.92 ppm for the methylene protons of the pyridine pendant arm. The heteroleptic Zn(II) and Mg(II) complexes were obtained by direct reaction of the proligand with one equivalent of the opportune trimethylsilylamide metal precursor M(N(TMS)2)2 in benzene or toluene solution at room temperature (Scheme 2 ). The corresponding homoleptic complexes were synthetized by using 0.5 equivalents of the alkyl metal precursors Zn (Et)2 and Mg(n-Bu)2. To elucidate the role of the neutral additional donor on the imine fragment, the homoleptic Zn(II) complex 5 was also synthetized (Scheme 3 ). This complex was previously reported by Jones in recent studies [52,53]. Complexes 1–5 were characterized by mono- and bi-dimensional NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis (Figs. S1–S17). In the 1H NMR spectrum of complex 1, for the signal of the imine proton a high field shift was observed (from δ = 7.75 for the ligand to 7.67 ppm for complex) indicative of the coordination to the metal centre. Two triplets were observed at δ = 3.01 and δ=3.77 ppm for the methylene protons of the pyridine pendant arms whose multiplicity was indicative of a high conformational freedom of the moieties. Coherently the absence of correlations among the protons of the pyridyl rings and other fragments of the ligand skeleton in the NOESY spectrum showed that pyridine nitrogen atoms were not coordinated at zinc (Fig. S6). The symmetrical structure observed for complex 1 in solution was similar to those observed by Jones for the homoleptic phenoxy-imine amine complexes in which the metal centres were tetracoordinated to the oxygen and imine nitrogen atoms and fully coherent with that observed in the solid state of an analogous homoleptic zinc in which the pyridine pendant arms were rotated away from the metal centre [54]. For the analogous homoleptic magnesium complex 2, a different coordination geometry was established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies (Fig. 1 , CCDC: 2,152,705). Single crystals were obtained by slow diffusion of pentane into a benzene solution of 2 at room temperature. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 of the SI. A distorted octahedral geometry was observed with the ligands wrapped around the magnesium in a mer–mer manner (Fig. 1). The imine groups of both ligands are in the equatorial plane, while the pyridine nitrogen atoms and the phenoxy groups are opposite to each other; the imine N1 and N3 atoms are at a shorter distance from the Mg atom (2.145(7) Å and 2.159(7) Å) than the pyridine N2 and N4 atoms (2.366(8) Å and 2.274(8) Å). The NMR spectra of the complexes 1 and 2 revealed that the different coordination geometries observed in the solid-state structures were retained in solution. In the 1H NMR spectrum of complex 2 performed at 25 °C, four broad resonances were observed at δ = 2.41, 2.68, 3.38, 4.28 ppm, each attributable to the four diasterotopic protons of the methylene groups of the two equivalent ligands. The spectra obtained at higher temperatures showed only two peaks with defined multiplicities, like those observed for the complex 1 in which the pyridine is dissociated (Fig. 2 ). Thus, at higher temperatures, a fluxional phenomenon in which a tetracoordinate complex is formed by reversible dechelation of the pyridine pendants is plausible. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra of the heteroleptic complexes 3 and 4 (Figs. S12–S16) showed sharp and well resolved resonances for the pyridyl imino-phenolate ligand and the bis-(trimethylsilyl)amide group. For zinc complex 3, a light high-field 1H NMR shift of the proton in the ortho position of the pyridyl ring (8.35 ppm) in comparison to the same resonance for the free ligand (8.45 ppm) was observed. Differently, for the magnesium complex the same proton showed a low-field 1H NMR shift (8.56 ppm). This difference could be a consequence of the diverse hard-soft character of the metals: for zinc complex a metal-to-ligand charge-transfer from its d10 closed shell to the π system of the pyridine ring could be responsible of observed high-field shift, while for magnesium a ligand-to-metal charge-transfer is a plausible explanation for the deshielding of the cited proton. Clear evidence of coordination of the pyridine moiety to the two metal centres in heteroleptic complexes 3 and 4 was shown by the strong correlations of the bis-(trimethylsilyl)amide groups with the ortho protons of the pyridyl fragment, the imine protons and the methylene protons of the ligand in the NOESY spectra (Fig. S14). 2.2 Polymerization of L-lactide Initially, all complexes were tested out under solution conditions (in CH2Cl2 at room temperature and in toluene at 80 °C), and in the presence of one equivalent of alcohol (iPrOH or BnOH, respectively) as a co-initiator (Table 1 ). Representative results are summarized in Table 1. In all polymerization tests, lactide purified by a single recrystallization from anhydrous toluene was used. From the polymerization tests performed at room temperature, a drastic difference in terms of activity emerged between zinc and magnesium complexes. With the homoleptic complex 1, the conversion of 60 equivalents of L-LA was achieved after 10 min (run 1, Table 1), while with related magnesium catalyst 2 the same conversion was reached only after 6 h (run 2, Table 1). The heteroleptic zinc complex 3 revealed to be the most active catalyst reaching a turnover frequency of 1700 h−1 (run 3, Table 1); this value is among the highest reported in the literature for polymerization of LA performed at room temperature, although it is significantly lower than that reported for bimetallic zinc catalysts developed by Williams and co-workers (TOF up to 60,000 h−1 in THF) [16]. The heteroleptic magnesium complex 4 showed a low activity, about half of that of the related homoleptic species 2 (compare runs 2 and 4, Table 1). No activity was observed with complex 5 even after prolonged reaction times (run 5, Table 1). A similar trend of activities was observed for the polymerization tests performed at 80 °C (runs 6–10, Table 1) and the best performances were obtained with the heteroleptic zinc complex 3. Also at higher temperature, complex 1 revealed to be more efficient than an analogous bis(phenoxy-imine) zinc complex bearing tBu substituents (100 equiv were converted in 2 h) confirming the crucial role of the neutral donor of the pendant arm in the catalytic process [47]. The strong increase of activity observed for both magnesium complexes could be due to the hemiliability of the pyridine nitrogen donors in the coordination at magnesium observed at high temperature, thus the reactive centre may be more readily available for the coordination of the monomer. Subsequently, the Zn(II) complexes were tested at higher temperature (130 °C) under melt conditions, in alignment with industrial practices (runs 11 and 12, Table 1). These conditions offer the advantage to eliminate solvents that are considerable source of waste, unfortunately very few metal catalysts can sustain these so drastic conditions [52,55–57]. On the contrary, in this case very high TOF were achieved with both zinc catalysts which showed the same trend of activity already observed at 80 °C. In agreement with industrial procedures, catalyst 1 was also tested in the ROP of a large amount of monomer of technical grade purity with BnOH as chain transfer agent (L-LA: Zn: BnOH = 10 000: 1: 100) at 150 °C and in the absence of solvent. Also in these conditions, the catalyst preserved its high activity and the conversion of 3000 equivalents of monomer was achieved after 3 h (runs 13, Table 1). Kinetic studies for zinc complexes in methylene chloride at 25 °C (Figs. S32 and S33) showed linear relationships of ln( [LA]0/ [LA]t versus time for both zinc complexes, in agreement with pseudo-first order reactions with respect to monomer consumption. The kobs were 0.028 min−1 for complex 1 and 0.975 min−1 for complex 3. For the polymerizations performed at room temperature (runs 1–4, Table 1), the molecular weights of the PLA samples obtained were in moderate agreement with the values theoretically expected (difference less than 23%) and the disperisities were always lower than 1.3. To evaluate the control degree of the different catalysts over the polymerization processes, Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization-Time of Flight (MALDI-ToF) analysis of low molecular weight PLAs purposely prepared were performed. The MALDI-ToF spectra of PLA samples obtained from zinc catalysts 1 and 3 revealed symmetrical distributions of peaks with a spacing of 144 gmol−1 bearing the BnO/OH end groups demonstrating the absence of undesired transesterification reactions (Fig. 3 ). However, when the reaction time was extended over the complete conversion of the monomer without quenching, the molecular masses dispersity increased as consequence of transesterification reactions (Fig. S24). When unpurified or technical grade monomer was used, molecular masses were significantly lower than the expected values as consequence of the presence of protic impurities that act as chain transfer agents (runs 11–12, Table 1), but in the presence of alcohol the control over molecular masses was repristinated (run 13, Table 1). Differently, the control degree over the molecular masses by the magnesium catalyst 4 was very poor. In the MALDI-ToF spectra of a PLAs obtained with 4 (Fig. S23) multiple distributions were evident with a peak separation of 144 g mol−1, this could be a consequence of the presence of more than one active species in polymerization medium. For all samples, the homonuclear decoupled 1H NMR spectra demonstrated the absence of racemization phenomena. 2.3 Mechanistic studies To clarify the different behavior of the investigated complexes in the ROP of lactide, mechanistic studies were performed by NMR analysis to elucidate the structure of the active species. Initially, the reaction between complex 1 and isopropanol was performed at room temperature, in benzene-d6 solution and was monitored by 1H NMR analysis. All signals of the metal complex 1 and the alcohol remained unchanged (Fig. S18 of SI), and no interaction was established between the two species, as confirmed by the DOSY experiment. Subsequently, five equivalents of lactide were added and after 10 min at room temperature, no significant variation to the resonances of metal complex was observed while a weak upfield shift of methine resonances of lactide was evident as consequence of its coordination at the metal centre. At the same time, the resonances of the free isopropyl alcohol disappeared and additional resonances corresponding to the formation of PLA sequences were observed (Fig. 4 ). All these observations were consistent with the hypothesis that an activated monomer mechanism is operative for the homoleptic complex 1 (Scheme 4 ) in which the metal centre acts as a Lewis acid toward monomer and pyridine moieties do not compete significantly for the coordination at the metal centre. As already discussed by Jones, the additional N donor in the ancillary ligands could have an active role during polymerization process potentially assisting in the proton-transfer steps by activating the external nucleophile [53]. This could explain the great difference in terms of activity with complex 5 and with analogous complexes devoid of an additional donor. Differently, the addition of one equivalent of iPrOH to a benzene-d6 solution of the related heteroleptic complex 3, showed the formation of a related alkoxide derivative (82%) and a small percentage of the homoleptic complex 1 (18%) (Fig. S19). The ratio between these two species did not change increasing the temperature up to 65 °C. After the addition of five equivalents of lactide, the signals of the homoleptic species did not change while the resonances related to the alkoxide derivative changed significantly and the simultaneous formation of oligolactic sequences were detected. Considering that also in this case the added alcohol was exhaustively consumed and the MALDI-ToF analysis of the obtained polymer described exclusively the presence of iPrO end groups, we can conclude that the alkoxide zinc derivative was responsible for the polymerization and a coordination /insertion mechanism was operative. Subsequently the same experiments were performed with the homoleptic and heteroleptic magnesium complexes 2 and 4. When one equivalent of isopropanol was added to a benzene-d6 solution of complex 2, the resonances of the methylene protons of the pyridine pendants resolved into two broad resonances suggesting a fluxional coordination of the pyridine nitrogen atoms because of the competitive coordination of the alcohol at the magnesium centre or to the pyridine moiety (Fig. S20). No significative differences were observed in other regions of the NMR spectrum. After the addition of five equivalents of lactide, the alcoholysis of the complex occurred, the alcohol was exhaustively consumed with the formation of the heteroleptic alkoxide magnesium complex and one equivalent of free ligand. This process could be favored by the coordination of the monomer at magnesium. At the same time, additional resonances for PLA sequences bearing isopropoxy chain end groups were observed (Fig. S21). These observations suggest the active species is the heteroleptic alkoxide derivative for which a coordination insertion mechanism can be supposed, considering the lesser coordination of the magnesium and the presence of the isopropoxide labile group (Scheme 5 ). When the same experiment was performed with complex 4, the homoleptic complex 2 was quantitatively produced, reasonably by a Schlenk equilibrium (Fig. S22). After the addition of lactide a mixture of species was formed. Reasonably the presence of the monomer as coordinating species stabilizes the heteroleptic species. The NMR experiments performed with magnesium complexes 2 and 4 are indicative of the occurrence of several reactions under the reaction conditions used for the polymerization, which could be responsible of the low control demonstrated during polymerization. 2.4 Degradation studies of PLA Considering the high tendence of the synthetized complexes to promote transesterification reactions, they were investigated as catalysts for the depolymerization of PLLA, by alcoholysis. In the last five years, several homoleptic zinc complexes with phenoxy-imine or phenoxy-amine ligands bearing additional neutral donors (from primary to tertiary amine) have been investigated as catalysts for the chemical degradation of PLLA [53,58]. The best performances were achieved with homoleptic complexes of Zn(II) and Mg(II) with tridentate (NNO) ligand in which the phenoxy fragment is integrated with two amine functionalities [49]. Initially, samples of a commercially available PLLA (M n = 50,000 g mol−1 Ð = 1.2) were dissolved in THF/ MeOH solution at room temperature. All parameters for monitoring of the reaction, namely conversion, selectivity, and yield of methyl lactate (XInt, Sme-La, YMe-La, respectively) were evaluated by 1H NMR analysis of the methine region. In these conditions, the heteroleptic zinc complex 3 revealed to be the most active, the homoleptic zinc and magnesium complexes (1 and 2, respectively) showed the same activity while complex 4 was completely inactive because of its susceptivity to the presence of protic species(runs1–4, Table 2 ). No activity was achieved with the magnesium complex 5 confirming the key role of the pyridine additional donor also in the depolymerization reactions (run 5, Table 2). As already discussed by Jones, in the case of homoleptic complexes, the pendant amine groups in the ancillary ligands could have an active role during both the polymerization reactions and PLA degradation process. In particular, during the degradation by metanolysis, the pendant arm could potentially assist the proton-transfer steps by activating the external nucleophile (Scheme 6 ) [53]. Despite the insolubility of the polymer in absolute MeOH, the heteroleptic zinc complex 3, preserved its high activity also in solvent free conditions reaching a good conversion after only 45 min. All other complexes showed very low or absent activities. To overcome this limit, additional experiments were performed in methanol at reflux demonstrating the best results for zinc catalysts 1 and 3 (runs 6–9, Table 2). All complexes were selective in the formation of methylactate when the reactions were performed in absolute methanol, as consequence of a degradation mechanism that proceeds by a progressive erosion of the polymeric chain starting from chain end groups [51]. The selective degradation of more than 60% of the PLLA sample to methylactate was obtained with the zinc complexes 1 and 3 after only 15 min by using a low catalyst loading (0.6% mol) and without dissolving the polymer in any solvent. These performances were superiors to those obtained with homoleptic zinc complexes based on propylenediamine Schiff bases for which a yield of 81% in Me-LA was achieved after 0.5 h at 50 °C in THF/ MeOH [49]. Conclusions The chemical recycling of plastics may represent a strategic action to limit the dramatic consequences of environmental pollution caused by these materials and to contain the consume of not renewable resources, coherently with the model of a sustainable circular economy. In this paper we describe simple zinc and magnesium complexes supported by phenoxy-imine pyridine ligands characterized by different coordination geometries. All complexes were active both in the ROP of lactide and in the degradation of PLA by methanolysis showing different activities depending on their structural parameters. In the ROP of L-LA, both under mild and industrially relevant conditions, high activity and efficient control were observed for zinc catalysts. NMR investigations of active species demonstrate the formation of species with defined identities for zinc complexes, differently, magnesium complexes are interested by several equilibria thus a mixture of active species are formed in the polymerization medium resulting in an uncontrolled process. The zinc complexes were also found to be the best systems to mediate the controlled depolymerization of polylactide by methanolysis. From these data emerged that the metal nature has a crucial role on catalyst activity and polymerization control, although these differences were less significant at higher temperature. These studies furnished useful indication about a functional design of the catalytic species in terms of structure of the ancillary ligand, nature of the metal centre and coordination geometry for promoting the synthesis and degradation of PLA Experimental section All experimental procedures are reported in the Supporting Information. coredata.dc:description: Homoleptic and heteroleptic zinc and magnesium complexes bearing phenoxy-imine pyridine ligands were synthetized and characterized. Several structural parameters such as the structure of the ancillary ligand, the nature of the metal centre and the coordination geometry were investigated for identifying design elements purposeful to improve the catalytic activity in the ring opening polymerization (ROP) of lactide and in the reverse reaction of degradation of polylactide by alcoholysis. High efficiency and control degree were reached with zinc catalysts while magnesium ones showed lower activity and a weak control degree. NMR studies demonstrated that, for the homoleptic zinc complex, an activated-monomer mechanism was active. Differently, a coordination/insertion mechanism was observed for the related homoleptic zinc complex. Significantly, the complexes that showed the best activity in the ROP of lactide revealed to be the most efficient also in the degradation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Zinc and magnesium catalysts for the synthesis for PLA and its degradation: Clues for catalyst design
